ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

THEFT IN ARMY CAMPS
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister of Defence (a) whether he will comment on the remarks made recently by the First Deputy Prime Minister on theft in army camps; (b) how many cases of theft there have been in the last five years; (c) how many culprits have been apprehended; and (d) what measures have been taken to improve general security and discipline so as to reduce theft cases in army camps as well as better the image of the army.

     The Minister of Defence (Mr Howe Yoon Chong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the First Deputy Prime Minister remarked in the middle of January 1982 that theft was a common occurrence in SAF camps and that something must be done in our educational system to improve the moral fibre of our young men. I am sure Members of the House are well aware of the measures being taken by the Ministry of Education in this direction.

    For the SAF, this remark of the First Deputy Prime Minister should not be interpreted to mean that theft is more prevalent among our national servicemen than among similar groups of young men elsewhere.

Column: 838



    Every year, 20,000 or so young men of 18 years of age are recruited into national service. They come from different walks of life. Some are fresh from school and eager to go for further studies. Others have left school, on completion of their 'O' levels, one or two years ago. Many have left school prematurely at PSLE or Secondary I or Secondary 11 level. Most of these have been doing different jobs for one year or more. From this rather disparate group of young men there will bound to be different standards of integrity and moral behaviour and the incidence of petty thievery, breaking-in, and stealing cannot be avoided. What the SAF can do is to try, through strict military discipline, education and moral instruction to get our national servicemen to understand not only their rights and responsibilities as citizens but also their obligations. The SAF will not slacken in its efforts to instil discipline, integrity, and pride of belonging in our national servicemen. In this respect, Mindef is gratified to receive the support and encouragement of parents, teachers, community leaders, and others who can exercise influence over our national servicemen.

    Mindef has constantly emphasized that the two to 2 1/2 years' national service should be an extension of the education of our young men. To this end, while discharging our main responsibility in providing military training, Mindef also trains our national servicemen in a variety of skills which will be useful in civilian life. The SAF itself inculcates strict discipline and adherence to the military honour code among our national servicemen. Mindef would like to believe that the young men put under our charge would have benefited in their moral, physical, and mental education while doing national service. I am happy to inform the House that there has been a dramatic improvement in

Column: 839

the last five years with the reported cases of theft decreasing regularly each year, from 159 in 1977, to 106 in 1978; from 89 in 1979, to 66 in 1980, and to 32 in 1981.

    Of the total number of 452 cases over the five years, 1977 to 1981, about half were solved with the arrest of 240 servicemen. The remaining cases were not solved.

    Of the 240 servicemen arrested, half of these were educated up to only primary level. The other half were from various levels of secondary education.

    The measures taken to reduce the number of theft cases in the SAF include:

    (a) Briefing officers and NCOs on the common methods of theft and the preventive measures they can take.

    (b) Regularly reminding servicemen at parades to take precautions against theft and of the penalties for stealing.

    (c) More security patrols and spot checks, especially during weekends, public holidays, and in periods of field training and exercises, when most of the servicemen are out of camp.

    (d) Severe disciplinary action against culprits, with sentences in courts martial ranging from two to 24 months' detention.

REDEVELOPMENT OF SIT FLAT SITE
IN DELTA


    2. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether there are plans to redevelop the area in Delta on which low-rise Singapore Improvement Trust (SIT) flats now stand; (b) what types of flats and facilities are included in the plans; and (c) whether the present tenants of the flats will be given priority in allocation of the new flats to be built on the site.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, as we have limited land for housing in Singapore, the low-rise SIT flats in Delta will have to be redeveloped for high-rise blocks to enable better utilization of land. However, because the HDB has a very heavy building programme

Column: 840

over the next few years, there are no immediate plans to redevelop the area in Delta.

    All HDB tenants affected by redevelopment schemes are given priority to purchase or rent HDB flats available at the time when rehousing is required. We cannot allow tenants of demolished flats to be given priority in allocation of new flats to be built on the site since they must move out to enable the site to be redeveloped. However, in a large site like Delta where phased redevelopment may be carried out, and where new flats in earlier phases are available, those tenants affected in later phases may have the opportunity to opt for rehousing in the newly completed blocks.

REVISION OF PUBLIC ASSISTANCE


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Acting Minister for Social Affairs, in the light of the present day high cost of living, whether his Ministry will consider taking the necessary steps to make an upward revision of public assistance.

     The Acting Minister for Social Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, during the last 10 years, the rates of Public Assistance were revised on three occasions: in January 1973, in March 1976 and in February 1980. Today I am pleased to inform the House that, having regard to the rise in the cost of living during the last two years and I must also add that as a result of constant reminders by Backbenchers, many of whom have been very vocal on the question of rates of Public Assistance -

     An hon. Member: PAP Backbenchers!

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Yes, PAP Backbenchers, of course - Backbenchers like the hon. Member for Punggol, the hon. Member for Khe Bong who is not here, the hon. Members for Jalan Kayu, Bukit Ho Swee and also the hon. Member for Changi who is now my Parliamentary Secretary - the Government has decided once again to increase the rates with effect from 1st April 1982. The new rates of Public Assistance per month are as follows: 

   $80 for a single-person household;


Column: 841 


   $110 for a two-person household;

   $140 for a three-person household; and

   $170 for a four-person household.
These new rates represent, on the average, an increase of 37 1/2% over prevailing rates.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Sir, could the Hon. Minister indicate what the figures were before the Government started its first revision?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: It was in 1973 when we made the first revision. I cannot remember the figures because I do not claim to be able to keep all the figures in my head. But the prevailing rates, in case the Member for Anson does not know, are: $60 for a single-person household; $80 for a two-person household; $100 for a three-person household; and $120 for a four-person household.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Hon. Minister not aware that there was a downward revision when the Government first revised the public assistance rates?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Sir, can the Member for Anson give me specific instances to prove that there had been a downward revision?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Were they not revised downwards from what they were? I am asking the Hon. Minister.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Sir, I am asking the Member to show that there had been a downward revision. As I have said, I cannot remember the figures for 1973. So if he thinks and if he knows that there had been a downward revision, I would like to hear from him the figures before the first revision was made.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I will supply the figures.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, whilst the public assistance recipients welcome the increases in the rates of public assistance, would the Hon. Minister agree with me that the increases as stated by him just now are still on the low side?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I fully agree with the hon. Member that these allowances are far from adequate.

Column: 842

They are not meant to be adequate in the first place. But I would like to assure the Member for Punggol that, apart from the allowances, the recipients of public assistance also receive supplementary assistance either in cash or in kind from voluntary charitable and religious organizations.

    The Social Welfare Department itself administers a number of private charitable funds from which the needy can get additional income, and among these are the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry Welfare Grant, the Lee Foundation Grant, the Charity Box Fund, the Silver Jubilee Fund, Robin Welfare Aid, the Singapore Red Cross Society, St. Vincent de Paul Society, the Singapore Buddhist Lodge and a host of other welfare schemes.

    Apart from getting additional allowances from these various welfare schemes, recipients of public assistance also get free medical treatment from Government hospitals and clinics, remission of school fees and free textbooks for their school-going children.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Can the Acting Minister for Social Affairs inform me whether destitutes who consider that their public assistance is not enough are also eligible to apply for further public assistance?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, as the hon. Member for Khe Bong is aware, early last year I set up a committee known as the Public Assistance Review Committee (PARC). This Committee reviews all the cases and if a case merits an additional award, the recipient will get an additional award.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, will the Hon. Minister say whether public assistance grants are withdrawn at any time and, if so, under what guidelines are they withdrawn?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I do not intend to answer the question raised by the Member for Anson today because a similar question has been raised by the hon. Member for Punggol, and I will be answering it tomorrow.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [5th March, 1982],

Column: 844



    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1982 to 31st March, 1983.". - [Minister for Trade and Industry].

    Question again proposed.
2.47 p.m.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for the opportunity to start off this debate.

    I rise in support of the motion standing in the name of the Hon. Minister for Trade and Industry.

    Notwithstanding the presence of an opposition in this House, the Hon. Minister would no doubt be receiving overwhelming support from hon. Members, for even the hon. Member for Anson was seen to be applauding him at the end of his lengthy Budget Statement some 10 days ago.

    The Budget is not the "go-getter" Budgets of previous years. If anything, it will be noted not so much for what it tries to achieve but for what it does not try to do, and there are reasons for this. In preparing this year's Budget Statement, the Hon. Minister has sought the views of various business groups, trade unions, CASE, National University of Singapore, and I find this move a highly commendable one. I hope this is the start of future trends for future Budgets, and I hope too that as often and where it is possible and practical, other Ministers will also do what the Minister for Trade and Industry has done. He has told us that he has taken the views of these various groups into consideration "where appropriate". In view of the disappointment of businessmen that there is a lack of sufficient incentives in this year's Budget to stimulate business, I wonder if the Minister has considered that most of the views presented to him have not been too appropriate.

Column: 845



    Much has been said about the fact that this year's Budget Statement is a cautionary one. There are, of course, good reasons for it being so, as the Minister has explained. This is not the time for giveaways. As any businessman worth his salt will tell you, during bad times one has to be extremely cautious and prepare for the worst, and I think that is what he is preparing for us and we know that the worst can be ahead of us. Last night we heard the news on television that prominent economists forecasted that America was heading for a deep recession, with a wave of bankruptcies so severe that it would be as bad as the Great Depression of the 1930s. The warning sounded by the Minister is not a new one. His predecessor had also sounded these warnings to us. Let me quote from Hansard (Vol. 39, col. 635, 5th March 1980):

    'We face the uncertainty of superpower conflicts in the political and military arena. We face the certainty of higher fuel prices. We face the grim prospect of the region being destabilized by external forces, and the oil life-line being cut. . . . . we are sure of sluggish world economic growth cohabitating with inflation.

    We, therefore, have the perfect recipe for trouble.'

    Last year, again in presenting his Budget Statement, the Minister said, and I quote (Vol. 40, col. 354, 6th March 1981):

    'We face difficult times. It is an uncertain world. There is disharmony between the superpowers. The political equilibrium in the world is precarious. We must be prepared for the worst but the worst must hold no fear for us. Recession, unemployment, higher oil prices, protectionism, regional conflict, security threats, international turbulence - all these threaten our livelihood. We cannot avoid getting wet in bad weather, but if we have made adequate preparations, we can put our raincoats on, and when we get indoors, change into dry clothes.'

Sir, these are the warnings which have been sounded to us previously. They have been sounded Again with good reason.

    True to his background as a former banker, the Minister has not betrayed the prudence and conservatism that bankers are normally associated with when he warns us of the turbulence afflicting some of the most significant economies in the world. It is not without justification too, for the statistics bear him out: 16 million people unemployed in Europe, of whom 3 million are found in a now-not-so-Great Britain; 9 1/2 million unemployed in the

Column: 846

United States, and 1/2 million in Australia. Certainly the outlook for 1982 is grim and the road so hazardous that to make any sweeping changes now in Singapore would amount to taking a risky gamble that we can ill-afford.

    In the light of prevailing world conditions, the Budget is as practical and pragmatic as it can be. It will not set off fireworks but it will give us all a little breathing space in a world full of economic uncertainty. It is, in short, a "playsafe" Budget.

    But there is another side to the coin: if we do nothing, we end up achieving nothing. True, there are positive aspects to the Budget. For one thing our housing programme will continue unabated and proper incentives have been introduced in the construction industry to enable it to mechanize its methods and upgrade expertise. And, most important of all, to make sure that Singaporeans get their homes faster. But what I am just wondering is if more could not have been done to pump-prime our economy at a time when increased efforts by all is so essential. Have we been so cautious in under-scoring the economic storms ahead that Singaporeans may in the end not be able to see the light at the end of the tunnel?

    I would like now to make some comments on certain aspects of the Budget Statement.

Trade Protectionism

    Sir, this is something which has bothered us for many years. It is a well-known fact already that to make ourselves less vulnerable to protectionism we have to continue restructuring our economy and move into the production of more higher value-added products. As the recession in the world economy continues, protectionistic action will increase and it will not be long before we discover who our friends are on the international scene. Take, for instance, the recent controversy in West Germany over the low fares offered by our national airline, Singapore Airlines. With memories of the Australian ICAP policy still fresh in our minds, we were treated to another example of protectionism. Singapore Airlines found itself

Column: 847

the subject of a campaign of harassment by the West German authorities because it was in a position to offer better services to travellers at prices lower and more competitive than others, including of course West Germany's own Lufthansa. Under the pretext of cleaning up the so-called "discounting" mark9t in their country, they imposed barriers and difficulties on SIA. Throwing all principles of free competition to the wind, the West German authorities succeeded in excluding SIA from what is apparently a lucrative market and in which their own airline was unable to compete efficiently. In what must surely amount to plain deceit on the part of the West German authorities, SIA found itself forced to sell fares at published rates, thus losing passengers and invaluable revenue to other airlines which continued giving rampant discounts. Suddenly not one eye, but all eyes of the West German authorities were closed.

    The lesson we learn from this episode is invaluable. Where national interest prevails and short-sightedness takes the place of international cooperation during difficult times, even the best of friends can turn against you. The doctrine of free trade, of which we are one of the strongest advocates, has yet to be universally accepted and under economically difficult conditions there will be growing trade friction amongst countries as governments, mindful of votes, hurry-scurry to protect their industries with quotas, tariffs, orderly market arrangements, product graduation schemes and what-have-you. What is more valuable a lesson to us is that we must be continually alert to changing circumstances and to re-adapt ourselves to meet these changes, and this we have done. The restructuring of our economy and the move into the production of higher value-added goods is our best bet in beating protectionism.

Inflation

    The Hon. Minister has stated that inflation in 1981 did not subside as much as he would like it to have, mainly due to rising food prices. I quote him:

    'Consumer prices rose by 8.2% marginally, less than in 1980. However, inflation in Singapore was again

Column: 848

lower than the inflation in the industrialized countries and that of our neighbouring countries'.

    Some consolation it is to the Singaporean to know that although he pays more for everything in general, his neighbours have to pay even more. Today the Singaporean pays more for a bus ride, for poultry, for pork, for a cup of coffee, for his clothes, for housing. And he has less to spend with as he finds that he has to contribute 4% more to the CPF. What he is interested in is not to be told how lucky he is to pay less than his neighbours, but what his Government is doing to make sure that the value of his dollar has not eroded faster than he can earn it.

    Too often has it been said that our inflation is an imported one and that there is not much we can do about it. To some extent, I think this is true because a lot of our needs are imported. But in quite a number of instances I do not think the Government should just sit back. Take, for instance, the recent controversy over pork prices. As pig farmers, pork merchants and butchers, and even CASE, started to slice up one another in public as to who was to blame for the rising prices, those in the lower-income group watching from the sidelines found themselves with another hardship. With a lot of pussyfooting on the part of those concerned and less-than-firm action on the part of the Primary Production Department the man-in-the-street found himself facing higher prices for a very basic food item.

    And it is not just with pork prices. Look, what happens each year around the festive seasons, especially during the Lunar New Year? Food prices shoot up astronomically. Let us not pretend that it is the law of supply and demand that determines prices. Clearly there are people exploiting the situation, pushing prices up at a time when they know everyone would like a little extra fish, meat, poultry and vegetables to celebrate a happy occasion. Consumers are at the mercy of profiteers, and what we would like to know are who are these profiteers? What is the rationale for allowing a few or a small minority to blatantly manipulate food prices for their own selfish ends and bleeding the consumer of his hard-earned money on a happy occasion? A festive occasion is a

Column: 849

time for rejoicing. For many people, especially those in the lower income group, it is the time to enjoy the fruits of their hard labour. For them, it is one or two meals in a year with a little bit of the extras, not just for themselves but for their children so that they can all have a really happy new year. But when they end up paying more, they are forced to stretch their purse strings in order to have this enjoyable time, Clearly it is time the Government took steps to prevent this ripping-off of the majority of the people by the unscrupulous minority each time a festive occasion comes around.

Tourism

    Rising prices, which I have just touched on, do not just afflict Singaporeans. Unfortunately it is creeping its way very quickly into one of our most important foreign exchange spinners, namely, the tourist sector. The Hon. Minister for Trade and Industry was right when he said that our hotel room rates "have increased substantially in the past few years and threaten to price Singapore out of the tourist circuit". Hoteliers would no doubt gleefully disagree with the Hon. Minister, pointing to healthy room occupancy figures and to glowing projections of three million visitors in 1982.

    But they forget all too soon something very basic to our tourist industry. We have to ask ourselves why does the tourist come to Singapore. Is it because of our beaches where ocean waves roll continuously on to the sand? No, there are thousands of beaches with sand whiter than ours, with sea-water much cleaner than ours, tucked away in every corner of the world. And it is the same sun that shines everywhere. Is it for sightseeing? True to some extent, more so in days gone by.

    What the tourist wants to see, whether it be in Singapore or anywhere in the world, is the quaint, the unusual, the picturesque, something very different from what he sees back home. Bugis Street has disappeared but in name. The fun of sitting at open-air stalls and tables along places like Albert Street and the thrill of wandering through Chinatown with its old buildings and oriental flavour have gone, as the old

Column: 850

are torn down to make way for the new in the name of progress. If, finally, all there is to see in Singapore are our spanking-clean high rise buildings and man-made parks, then the tourist might as well stay at home where he can admire the grandeur of the Empire State Building, the Eiffel Tower, and Mount Fuji.

     An hon. Member: London Bridge.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon: And London Bridge. We would be naive to expect the tourist to come that far to gawk at our OCBC Centre, or to see our Merlion spouting water at the harbour front, or to find out where Sir Stamford Raffles first stepped foot on Singapore some 163 years ago.

    So what does that leave our tourist with? Well, for one thing, he discovers, on checking into his hotel, that the roof over his head which he will have for a few hours a day will burn a big hole in his pocket. That leaves him with possibly two things that could attract him to Singapore.
